Salma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Salma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Salma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Salma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods & snack foods.

location.town: Tambo, Hinaplanon, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase feed and medicine for the pigs

loans.name: Armen

texts.en: Armen is an engineer but manages a clothing store to provide sufficient income for his family.  He lives with his wife, her retired parents, and his 5-year-old son. He opened his store in 2009. Demand for new products is high, so Armen is applying for a loan to bring in additional inventory to attract new customers.

loans.use: to purchase clothing to stock his store.

loans.name: John Karanja

texts.en:
John, age 70, has been a farmer in the town of Ndunyu Njeru for the last 37 years. He and his wife Hannah Wanjiku have two children.  

John was introduced to KADET Ltd by one of our field officers and this will be his fourth loan. He has paid all his previous loans consistently and promptly. He plans to use this new loan to buy seeds, seedlings, and fertilizer for his farm.

In the future, John hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds, seedlings, and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Nos

texts.en:
Nos M. works in the garment industry as a sewing worker in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is able to earn a profit from this occupation in the amount of about $2.50 each day to use toward the family's daily expenses. Nos M.’s husband works as a casual construction worker who spends at least eight hours per day in the construction field. They are good parents who try their best to earn money to support their child, who is enrolled in school. 

The house in which the family lives is old and in much need of repair, particularly since they have lived in this house for many years without the ability to make necessary repairs. Nos M. wishes to make these repairs, but she does not have enough in savings to make it possible. For this reason, Nos M. would like to request a Kiva loan.

loans.use: to make necessary repairs to the family home

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel G. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 26 years old. Liezel is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Liezel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages in the local community. She is also providing computer services to the community members. Liezel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Liezel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liezel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Liezel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and tools for the maintenance of the computer service. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Liezel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and tools for the maintenance of her computer service.

location.town: Port Area, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta O. is from the village of Villalin, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Benedicta is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Benedicta owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating "tricycle" (three-wheeled) transport services. Benedicta is just starting this business.

In 2011, Benedicta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benedicta is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the first loan taken out by Benedicta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories.

loans.name: John Chege

texts.en:
John, age 50, has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last six years. He and his wofe, Jane Waruru, have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET Ltd by one of our field officers and this will be his fourth loan. He paid all his previous loans consistently and promptly. He plans to use the loan amount in order to buy seeds and fertilizer for his farm.

In the future, John hopes to become a leading farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica A. is from the village of Purok de Oro, Iligan City. She is 51 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. To make a living, Jessica owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling fruits such as apples and oranges in the local community. Jessica has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Jessica is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits to sell such as apples and watermelons. This loan will be Jessica's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits

location.town: Purok de Oro, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana is 34 years old, got married to M. S., and she moved to Kot Radha Kishan some years back. Kot Radha Kishan is a small city in Pakistan located in Punjab province and famous for its dairy industry. She lives there in the area of Maan Singh Wala in a three-room brick house in a combined family system. 

Rukhsana owns a clothes and bangles sales business. She operates her business from her home. Her community clients visit her and purchase these products from her at reasonable prices. She started this business to financially support her husband who is a driver by profession. Her brother-in-law also lives with her family and he is also a driver by profession. 

Rukhsana is also a very good housewife and does her household work very well. She is a very supportive lady and tries her best to give comfort to her family with her work. She has given birth to two sons. She couldn’t educate them due to poor financial conditions. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her clothes-selling business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk that will allow her to offer more variety to her clients and make more profit. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In every loan year, she has maintained a good credit behavior and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rukhsana.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Agar

texts.en:
Agar A. is from the village of Dicoloc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old. Agar is single. To make a living, Agar owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting coconuts for sale. Agar has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Agar joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agar has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC.  Agar is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third loan taken out by Agar from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is a young mother of four children. She is 21 years old and married to a farmer. Her oldest child is only 6 years old. At her young age, Mildred has to learn to earn a living. She and her husband invested in farming and primarily plant rice crops. Mildred mostly helps in selling their harvest to the market.

Mildred requested a loan of 6000 PHP which she will use to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She hopes for their harvest to improve. She also wishes for her family to have better living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a fishing net and equipment

loans.name: Pedrita

texts.en:
Pedrita N. is from the village of Purok de Oro, Iligan City. She is 44 years old. Pedrita is single. To make a living, Pedrita owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables like eggplants & squash & also dried fish in the local community. Pedrita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Pedrita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedrita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Pedrita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional dried fish & vegetables. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Pedrita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional dried fish & vegetables.

location.town: Purok de Oro, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en: Samvel is an economist but has been managing a car repair business since 2009. He rents a large area which houses a car wash, a place to change oil, and a repair shop.  Samvel lives with his wife, who also helps with the business, and their two school-aged children. He has applied for this loan to pay for repair equipment.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to repair cars.

loans.name: Kung

texts.en:
Kung C. has been in the farming business for a long time, in Kompong Cham province. Kung C. plants rice crops as her annual business, and she can make a profit of approximately $1 per day. 

Her husband is currently a recycling seller: He buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires, cans, plastic products and bottles. 

Kung C. will use her loan to buy a plot of farmland, which she has saved some money for before. She is going to use this land to enlarge her rice crops.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland for her farming business

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel is 40years old, single, and has three children.  They live in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is the sole support for her children and her dream is to see them through university. For four years she has been selling maize and beans and the income generated has helped her to educate her children. Her major challenge is price fluctuation and her dream is to become a wholesale trader. Mabel is requesting a loan to buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: To purchase maize and beans

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida is a 29 year-old housewife married to M. A..  M. A. has a business selling groceries. He sells items like sugar, cooking oils, etc., from his store in the market. He is very good at customer dealings and earns good profits every month with his marketing skills. 
Sajida has three sons and a daughter. Her two elder sons are enrolled in a local school and the other children stay at home.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s grocery store. With the loan, she will buy groceries in bulk for his store.  
He has been operating this business for the past 8 years, and Sajida is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for him and earn him more profits in the future. 

Sajida is a resident of a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan, called Kot Radha Kishen. She has been living there with her family in a three room brick house for the past 8 years. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sajida”.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Harrison Nguri

texts.en:
Harrison has operated his baker shop in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 10 years.  He is 28 years old and married to Margaret Wangui. They have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his fourth loan. He paid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy a motorbike to assist him with distribution of his products.

In the future, Harrison hopes to grow his baker shop and be a leading baker in the area.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to assist him with distribution of his products

loans.name: Remalita

texts.en:
43-year-old Remalita lives in the town of San Francisco with her family. She is married and has 2 children, aged 15 and 9.

Remalita and her husband are both farmers. They plant and harvest rice crops. They have been doing this for the past 15 years. To fund their farm, Remalita applied for a loan of 6000 PHP. The loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. Remalita hopes to have an increased harvest and better earnings. She also wishes for her children to go to a university.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Maria Cristy

texts.en:
Maria Cristy C. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 25 years old and married. To make a living, Maria Cristy owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling products for daily use, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages. Maria Cristy has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Maria Cristy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Cristy is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products, like canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maria Cristy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products, like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Arevik

texts.en:
Arevik M. lives with her family and 2 children in Tolors village of Syunik region. The family is engaged in cattle keeping and land cultivation. With her own, very hard earned money she has been able to purchase a piglet, which is expected to become a mother pig and bear piglets for future sale. The family also has 1 cow and 1 calf. 

Arevik owns some land, but does not have financial resources to cultivate it. She has applied for this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer. The produce and income from this year’s season will need to cover her family’s expenses for the next year.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael L. is from the village of Poblacion, Mambajao, Camiguin. He is 26 years old. Michael is married and has 3 school-aged children. He owns & operates a habal-habal or motorela (motorcycle transport) services to the local community. Michael has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2011, Michael joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Michael is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Michael from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service

loans.name: Vahagn

texts.en: Vahagn Y. lives with his family of 6 people in Sisian. The main source of income for the family comes from agriculture. This young and enthusiastic man is eager to improve his family's living conditions and to raise healthy, well nurtured, and well educated children. Vahagn and his wife are planning to expand their family, and to be able to have sufficient funds they need to expand their business too, to increase the family’s income. Vahagn has applied for the loan to increase the number of cattle and buy cattle food.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and cattle food

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah, 30 years old, is a married woman who lives in the town of San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. She has 5 children, the oldest of whom is 8 years old.

Leah is engaged in farming. Her husband, who is also a farmer, does the major farming duties. She also helps in weeding and keeping the crops healthy. Leah sells their harvest to the market where there is more access to customers. Their rice farm currently needs fertilizers and other farm inputs. Leah applied for a loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) that she will use to fund their farm.

Leah does her best to help sustain her family. She takes good care of her young children and makes sure they are healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and other inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry feed

loans.name: Tith's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four low-income people who live together in Siem Reap Province. Tith V., age 52, has been selected to be the leader of the group. Tith V. and her husband are local fishermen. This couple has been married for many years, and they have six kids, four of whom are single and the other two married. She and her husband usually need to take eight hours a day to fish, in and around Tunle Sap River. They catch around 10 kilos of fish per day and sell them in bulk to their customers, who are retail sellers in the market. Tith V. will use this loan to purchase a new boat for the fishing business.

There are three other members:
B., a local fisherman, is requesting a loan to repair her old house.
T. is working as a fisherman and needs a loan to buy nets for her fishing activity. 
R. earns a living catching fish to sell. She requests a loan to buy nets for fishing.

loans.use: to buy a new boat for the fishing business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a 54-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a local coffee shop business. She lives in the island of Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her coffee shop business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 11,500. Teresita is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase coffee to sell. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Teresita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase more coffee

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia R. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 62 years old. Emilia is married and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Emilia operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as banana and sweet potatoe cues in the local community. Emilia has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Emilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase inventory and fund working capital. 

Emilia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, such as ripe bananas. This loan will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make snacks to sell

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina is a married woman who lives in Cebu. She earns her living by operating livestock and buying and selling of RTW (clothing)businesses. Her husband Rosalito, who is 58 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  They have six children who are between 18 and 35 years old. 

Florentina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florentina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000 to purchase feed for her livestock and clothes for her RTW clothing business so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her businesses. Florentina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her livestock and clothes for her RTW business

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick has been doing mixed farming in Kitale Town in Western Kenya for over four years.  He is married and has one child. His produce of milk, eggs and vegetables are all sold to the local market. He solely relies on farming to support his family.

Fredrick has requested a loan amounting to 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the improved milk production possible through the purchase of the additional cow will go along way in improving his family's well-being – it will supplement family meals and create a better foundation for his children's education in the future. He hopes to add four more cows in five years time.

Fredrick says the challenges his business is facing are diseases and animal feed shortages.  However, he remains optimistic in his ability to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a thirty-seven-year-old single mother living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda, with a dream of educating her only child up to university.  She operates a taxi service and a retail shop, and has been in business for three years amidst challenges in car breakdowns.  Betty needs a loan to repair her vehicle to continue her taxi transport business.

loans.use: to repair her taxi

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
Pablita O. is from the village of Pandan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Pablita is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Pablita provides motorela or habal-habal transport services to local community members. Pablita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Pablita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed to maintain service. 

Pablita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional tools needed to maintain her vehicle. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed maintain her transport service vehicle

loans.name: Avetik

texts.en: Avetik M. lives with his wife in Dashtadem village, Armenia. Avetik’s children are married and have settled in Russia where they can have jobs and earn sufficient income to raise their families.  Avetik and his wife keep a fruit orchard growing world-famous and delicious Armenian apricot, apple and walnut trees. He also keeps a cattle farm and 15 beehives, and cultivates 1 hectare of land.  Both his sons try to help their father financially, and their father and grandfather enjoy sharing the fruit produced on their orchard with the children and grandchildren by sending them to cold Russia to remind them of  the taste of delicious fruits from sunny Noah’s land.  To diversify his source of revenue, Avetik has applied for a loan to increase his number of cattle.

loans.use: to purchase additional cattle for his farm

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira lives in a small city called Kot Radha Kishen, which lies in the Punjab in Pakistan, a region famous for its agriculture and dairy industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her family for the past 4 years. 

Tahira  is 31 years old, is married to M. A., and has a 3-year-old daughter who has not yet started to attend school.  She supports her family financially by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from Lahore and sells to her local area clients.  

Tahira has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand her business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk.  This will not only cut her cost of traveling but also allow her to offer more variety to her clients and make more profits. She is hopeful that this investment will put her business into a more profitable position.  

Tahira is a regular loan user of Asasah's and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she has established a good credit behavior and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Tahira.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Wilson Kipngetich

texts.en:
T. Wilson is 36 years old and married to Domtila T., who is a farmer. They have two school-going children, ages 12 and 6. He owns a butchery in Chemundu Trading Centre in Kapsabet Town. He has been in this business for a period of four years, and his monthly profit is 6,000 KES. 

He has applied for his fourth loan from KADET LTD after successfully paying the previous loans well and in good time. He intends to use the entire loan amount to buy sheep and goats for slaughter to sell to his customers; the anticipated profits will be used to improve the business and also his family's welfare. 

His dream is to own several butcheries and become a famous supplier of mutton in the town.

loans.use: to buy goats and sheep for slaughter

loans.name: Azucena

texts.en:
Azucena L. is from the village of Letican, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old and is single. To make a living, Azucena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, milk, choco powder, snack foods and beverages in the local community. Azucena has been engaged in her business for over 28 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Azucena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Azucena is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, such as canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana M. lives with her husband and three children in Vaghatin village in the Syunik region.   Svetlana works as a nurse at the local Medical Center. The main income for her family comes from beekeeping and agriculture. It has been only recently that Svetlana had taken her loan from SEF to purchase more beehives. Her aim was to diversify her sources of revenue to have sufficient income during both good and bad seasons. Her beekeeping business was so successful that the additional income allowed Svetlana to pay off her loan before its due time. Now Svetlana has applied for her next loan to invest further in her agriculture business. She will use the loan to purchase wheat seeds, fertilizer and diesel.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer for her agriculture business

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Khem T., 50, has been earning a daily profit by selling fish. She always sells the fish that her husband gives her or that she buys from her wholesale suppliers. The family typically generates a revenue of US $8 each day, and they have been in their business for nearly ten years. Her husband is 50 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. Some of the family’s fishing equipment has cracked, affecting their ability to fish effectively and frequently. Therefore, Khem T. has decided to seek a loan to buy new fishing equipment to replace the old broken gear.

loans.use: to buy new fishing equipment to replace the old broken equipment

loans.name: Karen Rose

texts.en:
Karen Rose S. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, in Camiguin Province. She is 18 years old and is single. To make a living, Karen Rose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, detergents and beverages in the local community.  Karen Rose has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Karen Rose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and fund working capital. Karen Rose is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, such as canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en: Vladimir G. is retired.  He lives with his wife and 2 children in Noravan village in the Syunik region. Vladimir is a driver and has a truck. He also keeps a cattle farm and cultivates his land. In Syunik’s very tough climatic conditions, working in agriculture can be quite challenging. Nonetheless, it is the main source of income for most people. To be ready for the spring farming, Vladimir has applied for this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizer and fuel.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and fuel for his farm

loans.name: Felipe     Jr.

texts.en:
Felipe Jr. P., from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province, is 25 years old, married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Felipe Jr. owns and operates a service-based business providing motor or habal-habal services to local community members. Engaged in his business for over four years, he earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Felipe Jr. joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid his previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase tools needed to provide service, he is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to purchase more tools. This will be Felipe's fourth loan from HSPFI, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his service.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of service

loans.name: Loeung

texts.en: Loeung M. earns a living by raising pigs behind her house in Kompong Tom province. Loeung M. feeds them for their offspring and for slaughter. Her husband is a firewood seller in his community. The couple has three single children who are still learning in the local school. Loeung M. will be using the loan to buy more pig feed and piglets to raise. With this loan, she will provide her and her family with additional income.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and piglets.

loans.name: Virgintina

texts.en:
Virgintina is a married woman who lives in  Cebu. She earns her living by selling fish and operating a local eatery. Her husband Gregorio, who is 63 years old, works as a municipal collector to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 30 and 42 years old. 

Virgintina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virgintina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 11,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to purchase fish to sell so that she can continue to save up for her grandchildren's education. Virgintina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard A., from the village of Tapon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province, is 45 years old and single. To make a living, Richard owns and operates a business venture providing hairdressing and beauty services, and also sells silver-plated jewelry to local community members. Engaged in his business for over six years, he earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

Having repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase materials such as beauty products, Richard is requesting his fifth loan of 10000 PHP to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of his service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his enterprise.

About HSPFI:

The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals, like adobo & bulalo, in the local community. Geronides has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2011, Geronides joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Geronides is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Geronides from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase 20 bags of maize to offer for sale at market

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo P., age 41, is a local farmer in Kompong Cham. She is pictured here with her husband, who works as a construction worker, earning an income of about $1.75 per day to help support Keo P. in supporting the family’s needs. They have six children. The eldest is married and the others are still young and living with their parents.

Sok Pov is taking out a loan in order to buy a new cow because her present cow is elderly and no longer efficiently supports her field work.

loans.use: to buy a new cow because her present cow can no longer support her field work

loans.name: Shafqat Kanwal's Group

texts.en:
Shafqat kanwal lives in Kot Radha Kishen which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and famous for its agriculture. She is 36 years old and has been living there with her family in a 3 room brick house for the past 10 years. 

She is married to I. H. who operates an optical store in the market. He keeps in his store variety of frames such as sun and eye glasses for his customers. He also provides eye testing facilities to his customers. He is the only money-maker in the family. 

Shafqat is a housewife, stays at home and takes care of her family and does her household work. She has given birth to 3 daughters and a son. None of them are able to get an education due to poor financial resources. 

Shafqat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will utilize the loan money in buying more eyeglass frames for resale. He has been operating this business for past 5 years. Shafqat is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her husband which will enable her to educate her children in near future. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she has proved herself as a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shafqat kanwal”.

loans.use: to buy eyeglass frames for an optical store

loans.name: Expedita

texts.en:
Expedita N. is from the village of Kilon-ac, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Expedita is married and has 4 adult children. She makes &  sells snacks & other delicacies like rice & cheese cakes in the local community. She also buys and sells charcoal. Expedita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2010, Expedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Expedita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.

Expedita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like flour & eggs needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Expedita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is a widow and has three sons who live with her. After the death of her husband, she started an embroidery business. She is expert in hand embroidery and crafts beautiful designs on clothes and gives them a new look.  

She couldn’t educate her eldest son but she taught him the art of stitching. He is now a tailor and operates his tailoring shop in the market and supports the family financially. Perveen’s younger children are enrolled in a school and getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery materials such as beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk to prepare beautiful embroidered dresses to sell to different cloth shops for larger profits. She hopes that an investment will increase the profit from her business.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she established a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Perveen lives in a small city in Pakistan called Kot Radha Kishen in a 3-room brick house. This town is located in Punjab, Pakistan and is known for its agriculture industry.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy embroidery materials for her embroidery business.

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
The two people shown in the picture are Kuy O., 50, and her husband, age 45. They currently live in Kompong Cham province. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has five single children. One of their children is employed as a worker at the garment factory. 

In addition, Kuy O. also feeds some piglets in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. Kuy O. is applying for a loan as capital to purchase pig feed and piglets for breeding to sell.
